title: Australia's tight jobs market; energy stocks bounce on oil spike | Finance Report | ABC NEWS
description: The unemployment rate remained steady at 4.1 per cent as 17,800 new jobs were created in January, putting more pressure on the RBA to raise rates. The ASX rallied to just shy of a record close, supported by a batch of strong results and energy producers being boosted by a spike in oil prices, driven by renewed tensions in the Middle East. Daniel Ziffer explains. title: Racism 'deeply embedded' in Australian universities | ABC NEWS
description: University students have been the subject of "jokes" about "slanted eyes", accused of using AI, and have been scared to use their names on assessments, according to a landmark study into racism at universities.   Video by Grace McKinnon, ABC News Social Media Team.  Article by Liana Walker.   ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Zuckerberg says Meta no longer designs apps to maximise screen time | ABC NEWS
description: The CEO of Meta, Mark Zuckerberg, is being grilled for the first time in a US court. The case is addressing his social media companies and how they have impacted the mental health of younger users. The lawsuit alleges that the platforms have deliberately targeted the ways young people can become addicted to their apps. title: AI job loss fears loom despite unemployment remaining steady | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Australia's unemployment rate remained at 4.1 per cent in January, the same as in December, in seasonally adjusted terms. The participation rate remained unchanged. The data reveals workers landed tens of thousands of full-time jobs, putting pressure on the Reserve Bank to deliver a follow-up interest rate hike. It comes as the AI revolution threatens to change work as we know it.  IT solutions architect Ron Skruzny is one of those impacted by AI. He's spent a lifetime designing back-end systems for websites -- something artificial intelligence is now being trained to do -- at lower cost than hiring Ron.  Telstra recently announced it was looking to let go more than 600 staff as it accelerates the rollout of AI. CEO Vicky Brady says embracing AI is necessary "to put us in a position to be competitive" but no jobs have been lost as a consequence of the new technology. #ABCBusiness  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Man charged with terrorism offences after phones seized in Sydney | ABC NEWS
description: A 31-year-old man has been charged with terrorism offences over alleged possession of violent and extremist materials on devices. Police say they seized mobile phones, storage devices, and a knife after arresting the man at a Bass Hill home in Sydney's south-west. title: South Korea's ex-president Yoon Suk Yeol sentenced to life over insurrection | ABC NEWS
description: Former South Korean president Yoon Suk Yeol has been sentenced to life in prison for his failed bid to put the country under military rule. Prosecutors had sought the death penalty for the insurrection, which lasted just six hours, but has shaken up politics in the country. title: Inside Syria's Al-Roj camp IS-linked Australian women tried to leave | ABC NEWS
description: The ABC has obtained the names of 11 Australian women with links to Islamic State who have attempted to return home from a Syrian refugee camp with their children, before they were turned back by Syrian authorities.  The government has temporarily banned one of the women from entering the country, but the opposition leader has called for more to be blocked from returning. title: Bombing of Darwin commemorated 84 years on from attack | ABC News
description: Sirens rang out across the Darwin Esplanade today as hundreds of people gathered to commemorate the single largest foreign attack mounted on Australian soil, the Bombing of Darwin. On February 19, 1942, during World War II, more than 200 Japanese aircraft heavily bombed the Northern Territory capital in a surprise attack, killing up to 250 people and injuring up to 400. It was the first time the war reached mainland Australian soil, and marked the first of about 90 Japanese raids across northern Australia over the next few years. Courtney Barrett Peters has this story for ABC News Northern Territory. title: Darwin NDIA employee arrested for alleged $5m NDIS fraud | ABC News
description: A Darwin public servant has been charged over allegedly defrauding $5 million from the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) following federal police raids across the city yesterday. Kingsley Ebelebe, 47, a National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) employee, allegedly used his position to refer vulnerable members of the community to a NDIS provider business he co-owned. The Australian Federal Police (AFP) Fraud Fusion Taskforce had been investigating Mr Ebelebe since October 2025, and executed search warrants at a Lee Point residence, a Durack business and Yarrawonga businesses yesterday. title: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor arrested on suspicion of misconduct in public office | ABC NEWS
description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor has been arrested by UK police on suspicion of misconduct in public office. Unmarked vehicles, believed to be police cars, were seen arriving at Sandringham Estate where the brother of King Charles has been living since leaving his home in Windsor. UK police had previously revealed it was assessing allegations that Mountbatten-Windsor had passed confidential government documents to Jeffrey Epstein while he was a UK trade envoy. Europe correspondent Kathryn Diss reports from London.  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Trump threatens strikes on Iran as nuclear talks stall | The World | ABC NEWS
description: US President Donald Trump has renewed his threats against Iran, saying his military is ready to carry out an attack if Tehran doesn't agree to end its nuclear program. The deployment of US troops and warships to the Middle East has prompted fears of more conflict, and Iran has issued its own threats to strike US military bases in the region. Jennifer Parker, expert associate at the National Security College at ANU spoke to The World's Yvonne Yong about the latest developments. title: Life in prison for fmr South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol for insurrection | The World | ABC NEWS
description: A South Korean court has found former President Yoon Suk Yeol guilty of insurrection. Prosecutors had sought the death penalty for the impeached leader over his 2024 declaration of martial law, but the judge instead sentenced Yoon to life in prison. North Asia correspondent Natalie Whiting gave an update on the case.
